content.description:
This slabby shiny route starts on the smaller broken wide crack just to the right of the direct start of the main crack. Follow the crack up and eventually left to join up with the main crack 25 feet off the floor.

This involves a balancy set of moves that I personally wouldn't do without a top rope on, as the crux is about 20 feet off the ground.
content.protection:
pro to 3 1/2 inches. Anchors on top for a top rope, see the rock directions for how to set up a toprope.

A crashpad may make a trad fall nicer, but I don't think it will feel good dropping from the crux even onto a pad.

content.description:
Dawn Juan, but after the low crux, go up to a jug rail, then straight up over the polished face on some razor crimps to another jug rail. Then continue up some 5-easy terrain a short way to the anchors.

The crux is the face after the first jug rail, and is probably way harder if you're short. Â To me it felt like it was in the v4-v6 ballpark, but this was after mostly bouldering and hangboarding in quarantine, so who knows. I've heard reference of this being in a guidebook at 5.11+, which seems plausible (after a few burns on it I was able to find a few foot-chips that made the crux much easier than my first go).

As with Dawn Juan, there is a short 5.10d/5.11- ish crux in the lower section.
content.protection: Top rope only.  You could maybe protect it with something at the first/second jug rail, but it'd probably rip out some rock if you did, which is a no-no for being able to continue climbing here.
content.location: This route is climber's right of The Crack. If you want to set up a TR anchor it's one fencepost over from where the chains have been set up for The Crack.

content.description: The crux is about 10 feet off the ground, moving up and to the left from the good starting holds to some slick slab climbing. Join the crack for a few moves past the glass, and then a right-left zig zag to reach the top.
content.protection: Top rope only, not worth bolting to lead.
content.location: Set up the top rope anchor one fence post to the right of The Crack anchor. Follows a zig zagging line in between the bolt ladder and The Crack.

content.description: Climb the crack up the main wall of the area. Interesting crux is in the horizontal portion on the lower section of the climb.
content.protection: friends and nuts up to 2 1/2".bring a few 3' slings for a toprope.

content.description: Instead of starting out on the crack, climb the face directly below the vertical section of the crack. The crux is below any pro, so don't fall until you get up to the crack.
content.protection:
Friends to 2 1/2" and nuts.

There are also chains on the top of the crack, which can be accessed by walking south on Beaver Street, taking the alley to the right, and following the path behind the tennis courts up the backside of the wall. Do not climb the part of the wall facing the street (the one with the No Climbing sign), the neighbors have complained about rocks falling onto the sidewalk and hitting cars.

content.description: This is the far right climb at Beaver Street Wall.  It is steep, chossy and thin.  You'll see old bolts with no hangers and maybe two bolts with hangers.  Might be worth doing if you're waiting in line for The Crack or you want some practice with those new aid ladders you just bought.
content.protection: TR anchor off the fence at the top.  Bring some webbing to extend over edge.  Two draws if you're nuts and decide to lead this.
content.location: Far right side of Beaver Street Wall, maybe 20 or 30 feet right of The Crack.  You'll see a small tree near the base and a row of bolts without hangers heading straight up the rock.
